issue.title: Centos testing added
issue.body: Added testing as per [this discussion](https://github.com/baentsch/testing/wiki/Docker-image-goals) for Centos7 & 8. Arguably testing should only be nightly (iff some code changed) --> Moving new targets `centos-7` and `centos-8` down to the nightly section suggested (as would be testing target configs only either at check-in/`build` _or_ `nightly`).

comment.body: The Centos 7 and Centos 8 images pass on my `circleci local`.

issue.title: Updating BIKE's code
issue.body:
Updating BIKE's code according to:
- Drucker, Nir, Shay Gueron, and Dusan Kostic. 2019. “On Constant-Time QC-MDPC Decoding with Negligible Failure Rate.” Cryptology ePrint Archive, 2019. https://eprint.iacr.org/2019/1289.
- Drucker, Nir, Shay Gueron, and Dusan Kostic. 2019. “QC-MDPC decoders with several shades of gray.” Cryptology ePrint Archive, 2019.

comment.body: @drucker-nir I pushed an update to the algorithm data sheet (`docs/algorithms/kem_bike.md`), which is the final step before merging.  Can you confirm that I've recorded the right version in that file?

issue.title: KEMS can now be built using CMake.
issue.body:
## Build Instructions

To build on UNIX-y systems: `mkdir build && cd build && cmake -GNinja .. && ninja`

To build on Windows: `mkdir build && cd build && cmake -G "NMake Makefiles" .. && nmake"` in the VS Developer console. Alternatively, just running `cmake ..` will generate build files for Visual Studio.

To build shared libraries: `cmake -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON -GNinja ..`
To use (or not use) OpenSSL, pass `-DUSE_OPENSSL={ON|OFF}`
To disable (for example) all SPHINCS variants, pass `-DENABLE_SIG_SPHINCS=OFF`

To run all the tests, invoke `ninja run_tests`
To build documentation, invoke `ninja gen_docs`

## Things left to do:

1) Add all compilation flags after SIKE warnings are dealt with.
2) Add CMake and ninja to CI environments and update the build scripts accordingly.
3) Add the `copy_from_pqclean` templating.
4) Update README.

comment.body:
Builds and tests pass on my Mac.  The build was so fast that I almost didn't believe it worked.

- There were compiler warnings for SIKE and BIKE.  
- Can you add `--numprocesses=auto` to the `run_tests` target in `tests/CMakeLists.txt` to speed up tests?
- `test_style` fails since `make prettyprint` is no longer available.

issue.title: OQS-OpenSSL 1.0.2 CI tests failing due to undefined EVP_MD_CTX_new/free
Added OQS centos development image.
issue.body:
As per discussion with @baentsch, this is a draft PR adding a docker image which provides a development environment with liboqs and OQS-OpenSSL installed in system locations. Compilation of headers and dynamic loading can be done out of the box, and dynamic linking requires only the `-lssl -lcrypto -loqs` flags.

I'll add a README and refactor next.

comment.body: Is this PR still being worked on?  Or is this obsolete and to be replaced with something new?

issue.title: Centos 7 added; OpenSSL 1.0.2 removed; openssh integrated; test+dev D…
issue.body:
This PR replaces the previous one from my 'ism-identity (zrlmib)' that still shows a confusing amount of a few intermediate steps:

This PR 
- merges the build-and-test of openssl and openssh (optimising runtime)
- drops OpenSSL 1.0.2 support and old Ubuntu
- adds building of dynamic and static versions of liboqs, openssl, openssh
- adds the creation of docker images for running the system as well as continuing development in a clean environment (see README.md) if all tests passed OK
- adds Centos 7 support

comment.body:
> Ah, sorry @vsoftco, I thought we had to discuss the broader proposed API change of this PR on the OQS dev call before merging (should we expose the random API or not). @dstebila, did we reach a conclusion?

I'm fine with exposing the rand API in Python, although as I comment in my review I don't think we need to expose the custom\_algorithm function.

issue.title: speed_kem & speed_sig halts with Illegal instruction.
issue.body:
speed_kem & speed_sig halts with Illegal instruction.

Debugging stops at

Program received signal SIGILL, Illegal instruction.
0x0001112c in _bench_init_perfcounters (enable_divider=0, do_reset=1) at ds_benchmark.h:155
155             asm volatile("mcr p15, 0, %0, c9, c12, 0\t\n" ::"r"(value));

**Environment:**
Raspberry pi 4
Cortex-A72 (ARM v8) 64-bit 
Linux donpi 4.19.85-v8+ #1279 SMP PREEMPT Fri Nov 22 16:04:03 GMT 2019 aarch64 GNU/Linux

comment.body: Sorry for the delay in responding. @donbirno, could you see if pull request #583 fixes the problem? Seems to work on my Raspberry Pi 3 with Raspbian.

issue.title: Don't use cycle count register on Raspberry Pi

comment.body: - [ ] When merging, also copy ds\_benchmark.h to my Github gists account.
@dstebila @christianpaquin Let's chat about it during today's meeting

issue.title: Integrating Round5 from PQClean
issue.body:
Hi,

I am working on implementing Round5 into liboqs using the script in scripts/copy_from_pqclean/copy_from_pqclean.py. I am having trouble with what PQCLEAN_DIR should be. That is causing errors on my end.

comment.body: Closing for now since PQClean does not currently have Round5.

issue.title: Picnic compilation fails for ARM
issue.body:
When building on ARM (#460), if `--disable-sig-picnic` is removed from `scripts/arm-cross-compile.sh`, the build fails.

Compilation of `src/sig/picnic/external/picnic_iml.c` fails on lines 427 and 539 with "undefined reference to `rpl_malloc`"

issue.title: Standardization of the dynamic library names so that Mac and Linux could be supported
issue.body:
The current C library wrapper is set to build with liboqs.dll, oqs.so and oqs.dylib respectively.
In order to support Mac and Linux, the file name has to be the same.

Which would be more preferred name to standardize the C# wrapper codes?
"liboqs" or "oqs"

comment.body:
I'm a bit confused here, but also not an expert in this type of thing.  Our liboqs build system, as far as I can tell, builds liboqs.so and liboqs.dylib on Linux/Mac, and oqs.dll.  Are you seeing different names built?

As for a standardized name, should there even be a standardized name?  Windows has different naming conventions than Linux/Mac.  @christianpaquin, any thoughts on Windows?

To enable Mac and Linux support of the .NET wrapper, do we need a standard name, or do we just need to be able to point to one of the correct names depending on the platform?

issue.body:
## Build Instructions

To build on UNIX-y systems: `mkdir build && cd build && cmake -GNinja .. && ninja`

To build on Windows: `mkdir build && cd build && cmake -G "NMake Makefiles" .. && nmake"` in the VS Developer console. Alternatively, just running `cmake ..` will generate build files for Visual Studio.

To build shared libraries: `cmake -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON -GNinja ..`
To use (or not use) OpenSSL, pass `-DUSE_OPENSSL={ON|OFF}`
To disable (for example) all SPHINCS variants, pass `-DENABLE_SIG_SPHINCS=OFF`

To run all the tests, invoke `ninja run_tests`
To build documentation, invoke `ninja gen_docs`

## Things left to do:

1) Add all compilation flags after SIKE warnings are dealt with.
2) Add CMake and ninja to CI environments and update the build scripts accordingly.
3) Add the `copy_from_pqclean` templating.
4) Update README.

comment.body: I tried on the Windows Subsystem for Linux, and on the Windows dev console; both work but with warnings. I suspect many of the SIKE warnings are resolved with the changes in PR #558.

issue.title: KEMS can now be built using CMake.
issue.body:
## Build Instructions

To build on UNIX-y systems: `mkdir build && cd build && cmake -GNinja .. && ninja`

To build on Windows: `mkdir build && cd build && cmake -G "NMake Makefiles" .. && nmake"` in the VS Developer console. Alternatively, just running `cmake ..` will generate build files for Visual Studio.

To build shared libraries: `cmake -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON -GNinja ..`
To use (or not use) OpenSSL, pass `-DUSE_OPENSSL={ON|OFF}`
To disable (for example) all SPHINCS variants, pass `-DENABLE_SIG_SPHINCS=OFF`

To run all the tests, invoke `ninja run_tests`
To build documentation, invoke `ninja gen_docs`

## Things left to do:

1) Add all compilation flags after SIKE warnings are dealt with.
2) Add CMake and ninja to CI environments and update the build scripts accordingly.
3) Add the `copy_from_pqclean` templating.
4) Update README.

comment.body: I think the BIKE warnings can be ignored, they are only reported by Clang and have to do with the `{0}` initializer for structures. Judging by [this](https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=53119#c0), it's probably better to continue using `{0}` to initialize complex structs.

issue.title: Standardization of the dynamic library names so that Mac and Linux could be supported
issue.body:
The current C library wrapper is set to build with liboqs.dll, oqs.so and oqs.dylib respectively.
In order to support Mac and Linux, the file name has to be the same.

Which would be more preferred name to standardize the C# wrapper codes?
"liboqs" or "oqs"

comment.body:
Oops, I may have made a typo on windows file name being liboqs when it was oqs.

Mono has dllmap support which you can choose to resolve dllimport name to different names for other OS all you want but .Net Core does not.

Dllimport in C# is a little annoying to work with when there are different file names for the same set of APIs.

For example, the current C# wrapper is coded to work with oqs.dll. If I build for linux, I would have to use liboqs.so.

The application will not run because the file name does not match. “oqs.dll” and “liboqs.so” is different.

I could kind of solve this on my end by changing the DllImport to “oqs” without the file extension. It would search for the file name only. Then in this case, in order to run the application, I need to change the linux library to “oqs.so”.

Changing file name is the easiest way. The other is to be tedious and implement the same set of api 2 times for two different file name.

There is a NativeLibrary class in .Net Core 3.0 that let you dynamically load dynamic library. Though this also means older apps won’t work if the version is bumped.

issue.title: Picnic compilation fails for ARM
issue.body:
When building on ARM (#460), if `--disable-sig-picnic` is removed from `scripts/arm-cross-compile.sh`, the build fails.

Compilation of `src/sig/picnic/external/picnic_iml.c` fails on lines 427 and 539 with "undefined reference to `rpl_malloc`"

comment.body: I need to look into this. There are new updates on Picnic that might solve this (I opened issue #588).
